slides.title: Introduction to Environmental Components
content: Environment: the surroundings including physical and biological factors, perceivable by physical senses.
Physical Environment (Abiotic): Includes non-living factors such as air, water, and land, crucial for life.
Living Environment (Biotic): Comprises all living organisms like plants, animals, and microorganisms, depending on abiotic factors.
Earth’s environment: Broadly divided into lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere; interdependent parts.
slides.script: Welcome to this presentation focusing on Chapter 1, 'Components and Subcomponents of the Environment'. We'll explore how the environment, both living and non-living, surrounds and impacts us. We define the physical, nonliving, and living biotic components, dividing the earth into the lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere.  We'll see the earth as a complex web of interacting systems.

slides.title: The Lithosphere: Earth's Crust
content: Lithosphere: The solid outer section of earth that includes soil and rocks forming Earth's crust.
Soil Composition: A mixture of inorganic (minerals), organic matter, and water, vital for life.
Mineral Constituents: Compounds of Si, Ca, K, Al, Fe, Mn, Ti, and O; oxides, silicates, carbonates from weathering.
Organic Constituents: Polysaccharides, organo compounds of N, P, and S; influence soil fertility and productivity, even in small quantities.
slides.script: Now, let's zoom into the Lithosphere, which is the Earth's solid crust, encompassing the soil and rocks. We'll discuss the soil makeup, inorganic mineral constituents from weathering, and organic components, even in small quantities that influence soil's fertility.  Understand how fertility and productivity depends on these factors.

slides.title: Hydrosphere: Water Resources
content: Hydrosphere: Encompasses all water resources, both surface and ground water, covering most of our planet.
Global Water Distribution: Oceans/seas (96-97%), glaciers/icecaps (2-3%), fresh water (<1%) represents usable water.
Water Scarcity: Less than 1% of the world’s water is readily available for human use and consumption.
Water's Unique Properties: Anomalous expansion support aquatic and terrestrial life.
slides.script: The hydrosphere encompasses all water resources, both surface and ground water, covering most of our planet. Only a tiny fraction, less than 1%, of the world’s water is available for human use and consumption. We will also discuss unique water properties like anomalous expansion supporting life.

slides.title: Biosphere: The Zone of Life
content: Biosphere: A relatively thin capsule around the earth that houses all living organisms.
Limits of Life: Extends from 10,000m below sea level to 6,000m above sea level; this is where life can exist.
Resource Depletion: Biotic components withdraw food, water, and oxygen, but wastes exceeding assimilation.
Signs of Stress: Rate of waste dumping exceeds biosphere's capability, evidenced by various environmental problems.
slides.script: The biosphere is a capsule encircling the Earth's surface wherein all the living things exist. This portion extends from 10000 m below sea level to 6000 m above sea level.  Life forms do not exist outside this zone. We'll delve into the resource depletion, and the evident signals of stress on the biosphere.

slides.title: Atmosphere: Earth's Protective Blanket
content: Atmosphere: A gaseous layer surrounding the Earth, extends up to 500 km above the surface, supporting life.
Atmospheric Composition: Nitrogen (78.1%), oxygen (20.9%), argon (0.9%), water vapor (0.1-5%), carbon dioxide (0.03%).
Crucial Functions: Protects from cosmic radiation, and provides oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide for sustaining life.
UV Radiation Shield: The atmosphere screens out dangerous UV radiation and maintains earth's heat balance.
slides.script: The atmosphere is a gaseous layer surrounding the Earth, extending up to 500 kilometers above the surface. The composition of the atmosphere is Nitrogen, Oxygen, Argon, Water Vapour and Carbon Dioxide. The functions are to protect from Cosmic Radiations, maintain Oxygen and carbon dioxide, and to screen out UV radiations.

slides.title: Atmospheric Layers: Structure
content: Troposphere: Layer nearest the ground, temperature decreases with height, contains winds and weather.
Stratosphere: Above the troposphere, temperature increases with height due to ozone layer absorbing solar energy.
Mesosphere: Above stratosphere, temperature decreases with height; coldest layer of the atmosphere.
Thermosphere: Topmost layer, temperature increases with height, air becomes less dense toward space.
slides.script: The atmosphere is divided into four major zones viz. Troposphere, Stratosphere, Mesosphere and Thermosphere. We are focusing on the main characteristics of these zones starting from troposphere where temperature decreases with height, and stratosphere where temperature increases with height.

slides.title: Interrelationships Among Environmental Components
content: Constant Interaction: Mass and energy transfer constantly between lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere.
Two-way Linkages: Each sphere exchanges matter and energy with others, creating complex interactions.
Widespread Problems: Environmental issues are not confined, spreading across components, exemplified by acid rain.
Global Impact: Localized emissions can have massive global consequences, causing global warming and affecting all areas.
slides.script: Matter and energy transfer constantly take place between the spheres. Every sphere exchanges matter and energy with others creating complex interactions. Environmental issues are widespread and not confined. Localized emissions can have massive global consequences, causing global warming and affecting all areas.

slides.title: Ecology and Ecosystem: Defining Interactions
content: Ecology Study: the study of interactions between organisms and the environment, and among organisms.
Autoecology (Species Ecology): Focuses on individual species' behavior, adaptations, and interactions in its environment.
Synecology (Ecology of Communities): Study of communities and their interaction with the environment.
Ecosystem Definition: Group of living organisms interacting with the physical environment in a defined area; ecosystems vary in size.
slides.script: The study of Ecology is an integral part of Environmental Science learning. Autoecology focuses on individual species' behavior, adaptations, and interactions. Synecology studies communities and their interactions. We define an ecosystem as a group of living organisms interacting with the physical environment in a defined area; ecosystems vary in size.

slides.title: Ecosystem Components: Abiotic Factors
content: Abiotic Components: Non-living physical factors influencing life, divided into climatic and edaphic factors.
Climatic Factors: Include temperature, rainfall, wind, light, and humidity which determine an area's climate.
Edaphic Factors: Soil-related factors: pH, mineral and organic content, and texture.  They are the base for all land ecosystems.
Temperature, Light, Water: influence photosynthesis reactions. Species adapt to various conditions from tundra to deserts.
slides.script: Abiotic components are non-living physical factors influencing life. They are divided into climatic and edaphic factors. Climatic factors include temperature, rainfall, wind, light, and humidity. Edaphic factors are soil-related factors like pH, mineral and organic content, and texture. Temperature, Light, Water influence photosynthesis reactions and species adapt to various conditions.

slides.title: Ecosystem Components: Soil
content: Soil as Ecosystem Base: Major source of nutrients, and moisture.  Formed from weathering rocks and influences.
Soil Mineral Matter: From weathered rock. Stable primary (quartz) and secondary (clays, Al/Fe oxides).
Soil Texture: Size of particles: clay to gravel. Composition gives unique soil characteristics.
Soil Organic Matter: Humus, from decomposed organisms, forms clay-humus complexes, supports life and nutrients.
slides.script: The composition of soil is the base for all ecosystems. Formed from weathering rocks and influence the soil’s mineral matter, soil texture, and organic matter. Humus forms clay-humus complexes and it supports life and has various nutrients.

slides.title: Ecosystem Components: Soil Organisms
content: Decomposition: Bacteria, fungi, actinomycetes, earthworms decompose organic material.
Nutrient Transformation: Bacteria transform pesticides and herbicides into less toxic forms.
Nitrogen Fixation: Bacteria like Azotobacter/Rhizobium in legumes fix nitrogen from the air, enriching the soil.
Structural Processes: Actinomycetes and fungi bind soil. Worms and mammals aerate for water/air circulation.
slides.script: Bacteria, fungi, actinomycetes, earthworms play an important role in the decomposition of organic material. Transformation and fixation of Nitrogen which is an essential plant nutrient are done by bacteria. Worms and mammals improve soil porosity for better aeration.

slides.title: Ecosystem Components: Soil Properties
content: Soil Nutrients: From weathering, rainwater, N-fixation, decomposition. Available as soil-water solution.
Soil pH Scale: Measures acidity/alkalinity. <7 acidic, =7 neutral, >7 alkaline, influencing acidity levels.
Soil Profile: Vertical soil section with layers/horizons caused by material movement, indicates quality.
Biotic Factors: Live components. Plants, animals, microorganisms. They are producers, consumers, decomposers.
slides.script: Soil Nutrients can be obtained from weathering of rock material, rainwater, fixing of gases by soil and the decomposition of plant and animal matter. Soil pH indicates the level acidity or alkalinity of the soil. Soil Profile is the vertical sectional view of the soil. Live components of ecosystem have plants, animals and microorganisms.

slides.title: Ecosystem Components: Producers
content: Producers: Green plants with chlorophyll produce carbs, by photosynthesis, they are termed autotrophs.
Energy Conversion: Convert solar energy into chemical energy using water and CO2 during photosynthesis.
Food Chain Foundation: Produced food is either used by producers or stored and later becomes food for other components.
Photosynthesis: Plants convert solar energy into chemical energy using water and CO2.
slides.script: Producers are mainly green plants having chlorophyll. They produce carbohydrates by photosynthesis process. In effect, the plants convert solar energy into chemical energy using water and carbon dioxide. These are called Autotrophs (self-feeders) since they produce their own food. Part of the food produced by the autotrophs are utilized for their own consumption for survival and growth.

slides.title: Ecosystem Components: Consumers and Decomposers
content: Consumers: Living things without chlorophyll; they are unable to produce their own food.
Primary Consumers: Herbivores eat producers, examples include cows, goats, rabbits, deers.
Secondary Consumers: Carnivores eat herbivores, examples include snakes, cats, and foxes. Tertiary are Wolfs, Quaternary are Lions and Tigers.
Decomposers: Microorganisms, like bacteria/fungi; break down organic matter into nutrients for producers, like decomposers.
slides.script: Consumers are living things, which do not have chlorophyll, and hence they are unable to produce their own food. Primary Consumers, Secondary Consumers, Tertiary Consumers, and Quaternary Consumers eat different kinds of organisms for food. The dead organic materials of producers and consumers are their food for the Decomposers.

slides.title: Development and Evolution of Ecosystem
content: Early Earth Conditions: Absence of life due to inhospitable surroundings. Formation from dust and gases.
Prokaryotic Life Forms: Emerged a billion years later; considered ancestors to all present living things.
Elements and Chemicals for Life: Early Earth possibly provided elements/chemicals for life to begin.
Character Displacement: Organisms adjust to geologic, climate changes, and each other; behavioral adaptations.
slides.script: Development and evolution of ecosystem have a dramatic effect on future evolution. Formation of closed, membrane vesicles was an early event in cellular evolution.  Organisms constantly adjust themselves to geologic or climatic changes. As an example, the bats developed sonar to find the moths and the moths developed ears sensitive to the bat’s frequency.
